div.p: THE ENGLISH DAILY NEWSPAPER.

Price: ON PIASTRA TARIPE
SATURDAY, NOVEMBER 80, 1907.

div.head: WHAT THE AMERICAN PANIC MEANS.
div.p: "It is well that our people should realise the character of the tremendous disaster which has prostrated and paralysed the credit of the United States at a time when the crops are good and trade is booming,' says the "Star. "We have never experienced anything like it. For weeks the great banks have refused to cash cheques, and employers have not been able to get cash to pay their workmen.
"The New York correspondent of the "Daily Telegraph" says :

"'It is evident from the European newspapers arriving lately, and the cablegrams published here to-day, that you in England, while appreciating the extent and importance of the crisis from the financial point of view, have rather failed to understand how deeply this crisis is eating into the hearts and homes of people of all classes, and how seriously it affects the relations of everyday life. Now and then some lorid sidelight is thrown upon the tragedy of the situation, as on Friday, when Mr. Barney, late president of the Knickerbooker Trust, shot himself, and again yesterday, when Professor Underwood, of Columbia University, crazed by his money losses, went mad, murdered his wife, and. then cut his own throat.'

"He goes on to say that the American newspapers, desiring to calm the public mind, are either suppressing or failing to emphasise the truth. Our own information confirms this, for there is no doubt that the situation has been and is so serious that the Press has been unanimously engaged in a concerted effort to conceal the facts. The building trades are paralysed for lack of money, and tens of thousands of men are out of work. Miners, labourers, and mill hands are taking friglit and flying home. Hoboken is thronged with returning emigrants. Before the winter ends it is estimated that half a million alien emigrants will have left the United States. In the graphic phrase of Mr. Birdeoler, 'Ruin's ghastly face stares at all.'"

"Some months ago, when congratulated by a friend on his phenomenal popularity, President Roosevelt-according to newspaper report ---predicted that should a period of hard times' visit the country before his term of office expired, he would become the most unpopular of Presidents. Europe, according to a number of cable dispatches," says the "Literary Digest", "is inclined to think that this unpopularity has already overtaken him as a result of the severe financial shake-up from which the country is only now regaining its equilibrium.

"Thus the Paris ``Matin", once his ardent champion, now regards him as a fallen idol, and asserts that this panie 'will be recorded in history as the Roosevelt panic. He has proved his destructive capacity, says the same paper, by killing bears and wiping out billions of dollars in values. In the United States, however very few papers which were not already conspicuously anti-Roosevelt in their attitude attempt to saddle him with responsibility for the piano, although some independent sheets ask whether possibly the famous Roosevelt lack may riot be breaking at last.

div.head: "Le Progres."
div.p: Count Max di Collalto has acquired our Cairo contemporary, the "Progres". Mr. Kyriacopoulo will retire from the paper from the 1st prox

div.head: Egyptian Mail S.S. Co. Ltd.
div.p: We are requested to announce that all matters in regard to freight, etc, pertaining to this company's business at Alexandria, should be referred to Messrs. E. Barber and Son, the General Agent for Alexandria.

div.head: Department of Mines.
div.p: The Department of Mines is to be immediately suppressed. Lord' Edward Cecil officially informed Mt. Wells, the Inspector General of Mines, of the decision of the Finance Ministry in regard to this matter on Wednesday last

div.head: Khedivial Honours.
div.p: The various State Departments have commenced the preparation of the usual lists of grades and decorations to be solicited from the Khedive for officials, on the occasion of his Highness accession anniversary, which falls on the 8th January next.

div.head: The Suez Canal
div.p: Our Suez correspondent writes that since last Saturday there has been quite a rush of steamers through the Canal coming from the East, about fifty homeward bound steamers passing through in four days and providing average Canal dues of about 400,000 francs per day.

div.head: Coal Imports.
div.p: Between January 1 and November 28, 1,214,525 tons of coal were imported into Egypt, of which 677,357 tons were Welsh, - 143,201 Newcastle, 176,989 Yorkshire, 91,513 Scotch and 125,465 other qualities. During the corresponding period of last year the imports totalled 1,185,383.

div.head: An Egyptian Institute.
div.p: At the meeting of the Egyptian Institute to be held in Cairo on Monday, Abbate Pasha will read an addition to his note on "Le Suicide d'un Pharaon," Yacoub Pasha Artin will read an essay on the cost of material living in Cairo from 1800 to 1907, and Dr. Elliot Smith will read a paper on the mummies in the tomb of Amenophis II.

div.head: The Late Captain Roberte.
div.p: The Sirdar in a special Army Order, dated the 20th. inst. announcing the demise of the late Captain Roberts, speaks of him as an officer of great promise and ability and one who was devoted to his duty, and feels that the Army will join with him in deploring the lamentable close of a useful career of a gallant soldier and popular comrade.

div.head: St. Andrew's Day.
div.p: To-day being St. Andrew's day the Scotch community of Cairo will meet this evening at dinner at the Savoy Hotel. Needless to say the famous Haggis will constitute the most important item of the menu and will be received at the table with the customary honours by the 80 Scotchmen who are combining to celebrate the Saint's day of their country.

div.head: American Tourists.
div.p: One of the most comprehensive trips leaving ! the United States this winter to Egypt is Clark's tenth annual cruise leaving New York | February 6, 1900, by the specially chartered steamer "Arabic. The "Arabic" is one of the largest finest and steadiest steamers in the world, and is especially adapted for a cruise of this kind, where the stearner is practically one's home for several weeks.

div.head: Waterspout" off Alexandria
div.p: A very remarkable sight was witnessed from the new quay at Alexandria this morning, when a huge waterspout burst a mile out at sea. The waterspout had been drawing closer and closer to the shore and it was feared that it would burst over the town. Fortunately at 11.30 o'clock it suddenly collapsed and the sea for some time afterwards presented an extraordinary sight, the boiling mass of waters presenting a most interesting spectacle.

div.head: The Alhambra Theatre.
div.p: On Monday next the Lilliputian troupe of opera and Operetta will make its debut at. the Alhambra Theatre in the "Geisha." This troupe will be followed by . Fregoli, the celebrated transformist, the Sultan's tronpe directed by Major Bertrand Bey, Viennese Operetta troupe, Greek Melodramatic troupe, Riso's : Italian comedy troupe, Italian opera troupe directed by the Société Théâtrale Égyptienne, Italian Operetta and BaMet troupe, and to l. conclude the season the Bisini Cireus.

div.head: P. &0. Dividend.
div.p: Holders of Peninsular and Oriental ordinary, who get about 10 per cent. return on their shares if they did not pay more than present market price, will be gratîfied to know that the company has had a satisfactory financial year, and that there is to be no interference with the dividend. The directors, after providing for the usual dividend at the rate of 5 per cent. per annum on the preferred stock, will recommend a dividend on the deferred stock of 65 per cent. for six months, and a bonus of 3 per cent, fnaking, with the interim dividend of 31 percent paid in June, a total distribution on the deferred stock of 13 per cent. for the year. A year ago the distribution was the same usual dire the prefer deferred stock

div.head: MOHAMEDAN EFFERVESCENCE. INSUBORDINATE SCHOOL-BOYS. ARRESTS OF MOSLEMS.
div.p: The spirit of independence among the Mohammedans of Asia Minor, which has characterised the political situation in Turkey for some time, is even beginning to make itself manifest at Constantinople. Thus, the Achiret School at Beshiktesh, a suburb of the Capital where the Imperial quarter of Yildiz is situated, has just been closed in consequence of acts of insubordination by the pupils who have all been sent home. This school was founded for the sons of the chiets of the Kurdish and Arab tribes, hence the name Achiret. One can imagine the effect which this disciplinary mes." sure will produce among the tribes when the news bf the closing of the school becomes known. 1. Many arrests of Musulmans have been affected during the last few days at Constantinople thongh the reason for such is unknown. There are vågue rumours of the discovery of a plot against the Sultan ; at the same time this version is not generally credited. On the other hand, it is believed rather that it concerns false denunciations, .which happen so often in Turkey. Nevertheless, effervescence among the Moslems exists and is fed by the dearness of living. The attitude, for instance, adopted for some time by the Moslem populations of certain Asiatic vilayets, notably those or Ezeroum and Bitlis, against the incapable or venal Valis, has ended by producing a strong impression in the circles of Yildiz. Today again the Moslems of Diyarbekir demonstrated against the local authorities in consequence of the raids by Kurdish tribes and demanded protective measures. Telegraphic communications with Diyarbekir are interrupted and it is believed at Constantinople that the demonstrators, who went to the telegraph office will prevent all communication before the Government has taken steps to punish the Kurds.

div.head: BRITISH CONSULAR COURT.
div.p: Judge Cator, of H.B.M. 's Supreme British Consular Court for the dominions of the Sublime Ottoman Porte, commenced on Wednesday at the British Consular Court the hearing of the charge of forgery made by Dr. Noberto Bonetti against Mme. Gardette, a British subject. The plaintiff contended that Mme Gardette had fabricated a document in which Dr. Bonetti appeared as a debtor of £250, while in reality he owed nothing and the document did not emanate from him. Mme. Gardette declared that the document was authentic, all the more so in that it was the renewal of a former one stating the plaintiff owed her the money. The case continued throughout Wednesday and after hearing the evidence of the witnesses for the plaintiff, the witnesses for the defence were heard on Thursday. The latter numbered 15, six of which had been heard when the jury declared to the judge that they had come to the decision that Mme. Gardette was not guilty, the document being quite sincere. The judge said that he agreed with the jury that it was perfectly clear that the document was quite sincere and that, in view of the jury's decision before the conclusion of hearing the witnesses, he did. cleared Mme. Gardette acquitted. The judge added that Dr. Bonetti's plea was most scandalous, but his speech was rendered almost inaudible by the sobs of the acquitted defendant and the murmurs of sympathy from those in Court. Maitre Gottlieb represented the plaintiff and Maitre Sciortino the defendant.

div.head: KISWET EL MAHAL.
div.p: There were at most half a dozen Europeans assembled among the crowds yesterday afternoon, when the Holy Carpet was borne in state to the Mastaba el Mahmal at the Citadel. The occasion was of the East and conducted by Eastern authorities, and as such it could hardly fail to appeal to those few visitors from the Western Hemisphere who were present. The Citadel itself, Eastern in architecture and surroundings, the calm witness of scenes such as this for nearly eight hundred years, looking placidly down on the seething masses which lined the thoroughfare yesterday, the same and yet how different to the peoples who have assembled in ages priest, doing honour to the various forms of their creed, the same thoughts and aspirations, the same in feeling and purpose it may be, yet beating withal the unmistakable brand of the newer civilization of recent years.

And the escort too, true Egyptians in appearance and bearing, who, if lacking the picturesque dress of by-gore days, have still lost nothing in smartness by the change, the Infantry, perfect in drill and accoutrement who headed the procession moving as one man, the cavalry with their white steeds equally a mixture of Eastern physiognomy and Western equipment, the camels with their gorgeous trappings and precious burthen, these latter with the glamour of the East alone, the scarlet headdresses and the blending colours of the onlooker under a sky of fitful sunshine, gave an impression of the East, which, even in Egypt, the home of romance and ancient -splendour is not often obtainable.

The procession arrived at the Citadel at 4 p.m. headed by the second battalion of infantry, and were followed by a detachment of cavalry who immediately preceded the Mahmal borne on a magnificently equipped camel, and surrounded by a guard of civilian natives. Two military bands took part in the procession, and played while the various formalities were being gone through prior to the Carpet being deposited in the Mastaba. Last night there was the usual fete at the Mastaba, and this morning at nine o'clock the Khedive was present at the Citadel for the final ceremony

div.head: EGYPTIAN MAIL S.&.CO. "HELIOPOLIS” MAIDEN TRIP.22 KNOTS AN HOUR.
div.p: The Egyptian Mail Steamship Company's magnificent turbine strainer "Heliopolis" left Greenock on her maiden trip at 12.40 p.m yesterday. A marconigram from Rosslare received this morning stated that everything was most successful and that the boat was making 22 knots an hour. She arrived at Plymouth at 1115 p.m., the journey only having taken about 25 hours.

div.head: PLAGUE IN INDIA.250,000 MOSLEMS DIE."THE WRATH OF GOD."
div.p: A quarter of a million Mohamedans have died from bubonic plague in the Punjaub solely because they refused to evacuate the infected villages on the ground that Mohamedans are forbidden by the Koran to flee from the wrath of God. The principal Doctors of Law have now issued a judicial decision declaring that the Koran expressly enjoined Mohamedans to quit places smitten by Allah. The Govern. ment is facilitating the publication of an unlimited number of copies of this proclamation.

div.head: DOUBLE AMERICAN TRAGEDY. THE RESULT OF THE CRISIS.MURDER AND SUICIDE.
div.p: John Whitley, the wealthy capitalist, has murdered his wife at New York, afterwards committing suicide. The tragedy is the result of the nerve wearing worries due to the finan. cial panic. This is the tenth fatal tragedy directly attributable to the crisis.

div.head: MUTINY IN CONSTANTINOPLE. UNPAID REGIMENTS.
div.p: The "Daily Telegraph" says that three regiments have mutinied in Constantinople for want of pay, declining to proceed to Adrianople. "The Government appeased them by obtaining £80,000 from the Tobacco Regie for payment of arrears.

div.head: ENGLAND AND GERMANY. THE KAISER'S RECEPTION.
div.p: Prince von Baelow speaking at the Reichstag expressed his gratification at the reception of the Kaiser in England and his belief that when the history of the last ten years came to be written the cloud in Anglo-German relations which had thrown a shadow over the world for far too long would be found to have sprung from a great misunderstanding on both sides.

div.head: THE GERMAN SCANDALS. PRINCE SEEKS ACTION.
div.p: It is rumoured that Prince Eulenberg has applied to the Public Prosecutor to take action for libel against Harden and Bernstein as a result of the expressions employed during the recent proceedings.

div.head: OLDHAM COTTON DISPUTE.
div.p: DECISION OF OPERATIVES.
(Gazotto's Special Service..)

2 London, Saturday. The cotton operatives at Oldham have agreed to accept a 10% advance. The decision on the Brooklands agreement is due on. Wednesday but failing an agreement on the i meritsof the application for an increase, a strike at the end of next week seems inevitable.

div.head: THE CORINTHIAN CANAL.
div.p: REPORTE DE PURCHASE.
(Ga zottos Special Servicio)

London, Saturday, It is stated that a group consisting of the Greek National Bank and the National Association of French Foreign Securities Holders have bought the Corinthian Canal for 480,000 drachmas and formed a company to take it over with a capital of 1,000,000 drachmas.

div.head:
THE 1908 BUDGET
SOURCES OF REVENUE.
div.p: Further to our analysis of the Egyptian Budget for the year 1908, which appeared in pur issue of yesterday we give the following details concerning the various sources from which the countries revenue is derived

Drrror CONTRIBUTIONS. The land tax for the year 1908 is estimated at L.E. 5,063,000, an increase of L.E. 8,000 over the present year, and the dues on urban properties are placed LE 204,000 as compared with LE. 182,000 in 1907.

OTHER CONTRIBUTIONS AND Dues. These are totalled for 1908 at LE 10,403,000 against LE 10,640,000 in 1907, and are distributed as follows:- Customs LE. 1,880,000; Tobacco, Combac, and cigars L.E. 1,510,000; Harbour Hues L.E. 250,000; Lighthouse does LE. 20,000 ; Fisheries L.E. 43,000; Wood L.E. I

3,000; Hall-marks LE. 10,000 ; Judiciary lues and registration L.E. 900,000 (Registrasion L.B.797,000 and other does L.E. 103,000); Native Tribunals LE. 800,000; Mekhemeh LE 60,000 ; Various dues LE. 20,000.

REVENUE FROM THE ADMINISTRATION OF ReCEIPTS. This is estimated at a total of LE. 3,980,000 to which the Railways are expected to contribute LE. 3,525,000, the Telegraphs L.B. 125,000, and the Post Office L.E. 280,000. The figures for this year are Railways L.E. 3,200,000 Telegraphs LE. 120,000, and Post Office L.E. 260,000.

Various Revenues. These are totalled at L.E. 465,000 against LE. 370,000 this year and are classified as follows :--Investment of Funds L.E. 90,000; Interest on advances made to the Sudan Government L.E. 45,000; various receipts LE. 380,000.
RENTALS AND RECEIPTS FROM GOVERNMENT PROPERTY. For 1908 these are estimated at L.E. 140 as compared with L.E. 250,000 in
907, the difference being due to the deletion rom the Budget of the sales of Government property.

div.head: THE KHEDIVE
div.p: The Khedive will arrive at Alexandria from Cairo this evening and will spend several days in his Mariout estates.

div.head: CASSA DI SCONTO.
div.p: The paragraph, which we reproduce below from the "Anglo-Egyptian Mail," Jof London, contains certain inaccuracies, which deserve to be noted as they are calculated to mislead the public.
(1.) The Cassa is not settling its affairs by private composition," bat is paying its liabilities in full, and is voluntarily liquidating.

(2.) The National Bank is not receiving the 21% commission for itself, as manager of the syndicate : this commission is payable to all the members of the syndicate, pro rata to their participation, and the National Bank ets absolutely no extra remuneration for the very heavy work and responsibility which it has undertaken.
The paragraph in question runs as follows:

Severe criticisms have been passed upon ne syndicate, represented by the National ánk, which came to the assistance of the assa di Sconto, advancing £300,000 to that institution. The assertion is made that this Behaviour" lent the money at 104 per cent. According to the information we have been able to obtain, the report emanates from ill disposed persons and is altogether baseless. The National Bank, acting on behalf of the indicatep is advancing the necessary funds to enable the Cassa di Sconto to settle its affairs by private composition, such advances to Bar interest at 1 per cent. over and above the Bank of England rate, with a minimum of per cent. As security for the advances the assa di Sconto has transferred to the National Bank debts to it (the Cassa) representing some £750,000. It has, in addition, ortgaged the building, which it owns, inherit Pasha Street, Alexandria. The sims allied by the above debts will rank on pcount in payment of the amount due to the
Indicate, which is payable on June 30, 1909, unless further deferred. The National Bank,
manager for the syndicate, receives a commission of 24 per cent. on all moneys recover
as compensation for costs and personal barges incurred by the syndicate as well as compensation for its assistance in the liquidation.

div.head:
THE GERMAN HOSPITAL
DETAILS OF BUILDING.
div.p: To-morrow afternoon the foundation stone of the new Deaconesses Hospital at Alexandria will be laid and in the following notes our readers may find a brief account of the project for the new hospital and its future accommodation.

The ground on which the new buildings are to be erected has a total area of 20,600 square metres. It was parehased in 1905 from the Finance Ministry for half its actual value on condition that it should always be used for a hospital building. The site is excellent on one of the highest elevations in the vicinity of Alexandris, the ground lying 21 metres above sea level. It is easily reached from the town and will, when the road schemes of the Municipality are completed in the immediate neighbourhood, be surrounded on three sides by broad streets none of them less than 16 metres in width

The project itself presents, what is known in medico-technical language, as a combined "Block and Pavilion" system. The main body of the construction is on the west side, i.e. that is nearest to the Rue de la Cie des Eaux. the Administration block, a three storied building which accommodates 1st, 2nd, and 3rd. class patients and contains the quarters for the Deaconesses.

Next to it follows towards the east a two storied block containing the section for operations. There are two large operating rooms entirely separate from each other for septie Bod aseptic treatment. This block contains on the sheltered side very large kitchens and a boiler house; both in a basement deeply sunk into the ground.

Finally we have furthest to the east a separate two storied pavillon. This is intended principally for those diseases which without being contagious necessitate a complete se. paration from the other sections Besides Europeans, it will be mostly natives who will be accommodated here. This block will also contain the Polyclinic. All the building blocks above mentioned will be connected with each other by a covered passage and form thus one whole, easily controlled and yet easily separated from the other sections; a measure which especially in the case of the operating rooms is very wise and of great importance.

Turning to the south from the main building just described, we find the isolation wards For infectious diseases. These are placed right against the south boundary far away from the main blocks and at a safe distance from each other, one separate ward for small-pox' and other semi-detached ward for various other liseases. Both these buildings have entirely separate service with male nurses and sisters of their own. Lastly we have the mortuary, a small independent building placed at the south-east corner of the premises.

The total area built over will be 4000 square meters after the complete project is carried at. This leaves 16,600 square metres of open space, which will be taken up by gardens, approach roads and courtyards. Without sacrificing too much of the latter, there is therefore room enough for future expansion.
The following is the number of beds provided for in the various buildings : Administrative Block, 108 beds; Pavilion, 86 beds, 13

194 beds in all for the main buildings, besides 33 beds in the Isolation wards. In times of high pressure, when all the rooms are all up, the hospital can therefore accommodate a total number of about 230 beds. As our readers may already know, the funds or the construction of the new hospital have been principally provided for by the sale of the Id property in Moharram Bey, which was nally concluded early this year with the Société des Entreprises Urbaines" at a highly advantageous price.

Unfortunately the building rates had, since he original estimates were made, risen to such exorbitant height, that, when the public adjudication for the new hospital took place last summer, it was found that the cost of the ew construction swallowed up the whole capital at the disposal of the committee. They were therefore compelled, very much against their will, to cut off the east pavilion from the present project and decided to postpone its construction to more favourable times in future. But even the "torso" which will be erected now provides considerably more and better accommodation than what can be found in the old hospital.

Among the special features which distinguish this hospital from others built in Egypt and which, reserves to it a place among the host modern and complete establishments of is kind in the country, we may mention:

Medico mechanical room Roentgen cham. er, permanent bath arrangements, heating contrivance for all the wand by hot-water system, steam cooking apparatus for kitchen, large lift adapted for bed and stretcher transport, and finally the great spaciousness of the vards which allows 60 cubic metres of air pace per bed.
We must sincerely congratulate the committee on what has been so far attained by its efforts and hope that in the near future we will see the entire scheme realised

We call the following from a Lonion con ( temporary :

Sir Eldon Gorst, Lord Cromer's successor in Egypt, has, writes a Cairo correspondent, managed to shock Caim not that people think it will do Cairo any harm - by driving his own motor car, and by calling on the Duke and Duchess of Devonshire clad in white duck trousers, grey coat, and soft felt hat.
The Earl of Crawford and Balcartes with his family and suite have arrived from Port Said at Cairo and are staying at the Continental Hotel

Judge Cator, of H.B.M's. Supreme Consular Court for the dominions of the Sublime Ottoman Porte, will open the sessions at the Consulate, Alexandria, on the 5th prox. and will remain here until the 17th prox.

The marriage of Mr. Guy Foster to Aida, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Borchgrevink will be celebrated at St. Mark's Church, Alexandria, on Thursday December 19th at 20 p.m. A reception after the service will be held at Cliff House, Ramleh.

Mr. Kebedgy, Law Professor at the Berne University, has been appointed Greek Councillor at the Mixed Court of Appeal. It is believed that Mr. Kebedgy, whose knowledge of legal matters is most intimate, was! urged directly by King George to accept this post.
Colonel Thompson and his family have returned with their dahabieh from the Nile and, before leaving for India, are again staying at the Continental Hotel.

div.head: UNITED HOTELS OF EGYPT
div.p: The extraordinary general meeting of the shareholders of the United Hotels of Egypt was held at the offices of the Company on Thursday last, but as the necessary quorum was not present the meeting was adjourned until Thursday next, the 5th December at 4 o'clock in the afternoon, when the proposition of M. Adolphe Cattaui for the liquidation of the society will doubtless be approved, n o understanding that proxies carrying an overwhelming majority in favor of liquidation have already been deposited with the Company. We understand that the reimbursement of 6)per share on those shares having 10/- paid and 1/- per share on those having 5/- paid, will be affected out of the liquid funds now lying at the bank, and the remainder will be paid after the rejale of the company's lands which were purchased at exceptionally low prices.

THE GERMAN BUDGET.
PRINCE VON BUELOW'S SPEECH.
GERMANY NO SODOM.

BERLIN, November 29.1 Reichstag. In the debate on the Budget 'rince von Buelow, replying to a reference to the Harden trial, denounced the comparison of the conditions revealed with those of the declining Roman Empire. He said Germany las no Sodom. The purity of the Emperor's fe and house was emblematic of the nation's fe. He ridiculed the possibility of any cama la influencing the Monarch Emperor's self-reliant and independent character.**

Heart Stengel, with reference to the Badget, said that the statement that a considerable deficit existed must be faced. The process of improving the imperial finances could not be postponed by the Government. He proposed to effect an improvement by means of indirect taxation. The Budget has been drafted in the spirit of the greatest economy but the economy in the case of the army and navy could become the greatest waste. Admiral Tirpitz explaining the navy bill said that the fleet would be permanently maintained at the high level of other ations.
(Reuter)

div.head: THE TOMB OF QUEEN THYL.
div.p: At the last meeting of the Society of Biblical Archeology, held on the 13th inst., Mr. F. Legge in the chair. -A paper by Mr.E. R. Ayrton, entitled The Tomb of Queen Thyit' was read by the Secretary, and well illustrated by lantern slides. In this the author described his discovery, while working for Mr. Theodoro Davis at the Biban el-Molukor Valley of the Kings, of a tomb containing a huge wooden shrine covered with gold-leaf, and bearing an inscription to the effect that it was made by King Khuenaten (the famous "heretic" king)

for his mother Queen Thyi. Near it stood a couch, on which was laid a coffin containing a mimmy, which the infiltration of water had reduced to a skeleton. The lid of the coffin bore an erased cartouche, and the lids of the canopic jars containing the viscera, instead of | The usual heads of the tour Genii of the West, were carved into a likeness of the queen. Round the skull was a gold crown in the form of a vulture with displayed wings, which was put on the hind part before. A small part of the usual tomb-furniture was scattered about the tomb, including the instruments used in the ceremony of the "Opening of the Mouth," one of which bore the queen's name. Dr. Elliott Sunith, however, upon examining the remains, pronounced them to be those of a young man not older than twenty-five. Sir Henry Howorth, Mr. H. R. Hall, the Hon. W. E. Trefusis, and the Secretary (Mr. W. L. Nash) also spoke ; and the Chairman read an extract from communication by Mr. Maspero, suggesting that the body was that of Queen Thyi's son-in-law. Saan Kit, the immediate successor of "the beretic," and that his mummy had been substi: tuted for hers in the hasté caused by its clandestine removal from Tel-el-Amarna to escape the vengeance of the priests of Amen-an opinion which agreed with that of Mr. H. R, Hall expressed earlier in the discussion.

div.head: PORT SUDAN.
div.p: CUSTOMS AND REVENUE.

The Custom House in Port Sudan was opened eighteen months ago and great credit is due to Miralai Hayes Sadler Bey, the Director of Sudan Customs, for having so successfully overcome, the many difficulties, which had to be encountered in organising his department, for up to the end of 1905 no Customs Administration existed in the Sudan, The Customs buildings consist of offices and four stores, each 100 by 40 metres. More stores will be subsequently constructed The buildings are of coraline line stone. The local customs are under the control of Mr. Echlin. The organisation of a Statistical Department was begun in February last. Mr. Robinson, the Inspector of Accounts, is engaged on the compilation of elaborate returns for Port Sudan and Suakim and it is intended shortly to publish the returns every month as is done by the Egyptian Customs Administration. -

Port Sudan is successfully competing with Mombasa for the Belgian Congo trade. All the imports for the Lado Enclave come by this route and eventually all the Congo trade is expected to come by way of Port Sudan instead of Mombasa. The question as to how the new port competes with the Nile route for imports is interesting. It is found that for imports South of the Atbara, Port Sudan is competing with the old route via Alexandria and the Nile. Last year the imports arriving at Khartoum by this route were practically equal. The gum exports now all come by way of Port Sudan instead of by the Nile with the exception of a very small quantity. For example these exports for the nine months of the present year, from the 1st January to the 30th September, which practically embraces all the gum season, amounted to 7,676,370 kilos via Port Sudan as against 196,000 via Halfa during the same period.

CUSTOMS RECEIPTS. The receipts from import duty at Port Sudan from the 1st January up to the 10th inst. amounted to L.E. 25,190, of which Government cargo was responsible for L.E. 12,094. The corresponding totals from import duty during the same period last year was LE. 14,736. The total amount from indirect and direct revenue during this period was L E. 37,550, as against LE. 18,785 during the same time last year.
The figures for the three quarters of this year were as follows :

January 1st-March 31st. Import Duty. LE. 8,519, as against L.E. 341 for corresponding period last year. Of the import duty L.E. 4,113 were for Government cargo. Export duty, L.E. 320. Tobacco and Tombac, L.E. 614. Total, direct and indirect revenue, LE. 11,766, as against L.E. 1,012 for the first quarter of 1905. The insignificant figures for the preceding year are due the fact that a regular customs administration only came into being in 1906.

First and second quarters, from 1st January to 30th June. Import duty, L.E. 15,441, as against L.E. 4,692 for the same period in 1906. The Government cargo accounted for L.E. 7,404. Export Duty, LE 717. Tobacco and tombac, L.E. 1,035. Total of direct and indirect revenue, LE 22,753, as against L.E. 6,338 for the corresponding six months in 1906.

The three quarters up to 30th September. Import duty, L.E. 22,281, as against L.E. 12,084 for the same period in 1906. Of the import duty, Government cargo was responsible for LE. 10,764. Export duty, L.E. 930. The export duty for the first nine months of the preceding year only amounted to L.E. 69 Tobacco and tombac, L E. 2,050. Total direct and indirect revenue, LE. 33,403, as against LE. 15,463 for the same period in 1906.

The import duty on tobacco and tombae at Port Sudan from January 1st up to the 10th inst. totalled L.E. 2,305 as against L.E. 161 for the corresponding time in the preceding year. This large increase is due to the fact that tombac is now cleared at Port Sudan instead of Suakim By special arrangement with Khalil Pasha Khayat, the concessionaire, tombae imported at Suakim pays 204 millièmes per oke, of which 160 millièmes go to the Government and 44 millièmes to the concessionaire. The actual revenue obtained by the Government from the Suakim imports of tombac from the 1st January to the 11th inst. amounted to L.E. 1,458 as against LE 1,858 for the same period last year. The reason is that these imports are now cleared at Port Sudan. It comes from India and the merchants at the latter port only pay 164 millièmes per oke.
The trade of Suakim will be the subject of a | separate article.

Port Sudan, being the port of Khartoum, the following customs returns statistics will be useful. The total revenue, direct and indirect from the Khartoum customs, from the 1st January to the 31st October last, amounted to L. E. 34,191, of which LE, 31,644 were from royalties due from provinces, etc.

The export duty during these ten months amounted to L.E. 303. During the same period last year the total revenue amounted to LE. 27,654, of which royalties accounted for L.E. 24,931. The export duty during this time came to L.E. 298.

The total revenge of the Halfa customs during these ten months of the present year amounts to LE. 1,845, as against L.E. 1,078 for the same period in 1906. Of these totals the paroles post import duty amounted to LE. 1,798 to the 31st alto. as against LE 1,055 for the corresponding ten months last year. In all the above figures it must be remem| bered that there is no fiscal barrier between Egypt and the Sudan, and articles, which have paid duty in Egypt, are admitted free into the Sudan

div.head: SPORTS AND PLAY.
div.p: K. S. C

POLO MATCHES. Two matches were played at Ghezireh on Thursday. The match ground was in excellent condition which probably nocounted for the extra good play of the competitors. The first match was between the subalterns of the 60th | Rifles versus the Coldstream Guards subalterns, the latter winning by 4 goals to 3. At the end of the 3rd Chukker the Guards were 41 goals to 1, but the both then made a great effort, and, with the Guards being rather too confident, Dearly bought the score level. Mr. Tritton is away just now, and with Sir Walter Barttelot still unable to play on account of his injured arm, the Guards team is not quite representative. Messrs. Bentinek and Tolle mache played a good game for the Guards, and Mr. Watts Rassell has improved considerably. For the 60th Mr. Seymour as usual was the great support to his side, and Mr. Hope at back decidedly did his share. He ought, with his-weight and strength, with regalar practice, to develop into a very strong back. Of the younger players in this Regiment Mr. Saunders might be given encouragement, he has a good eye and some very useful strokes.
TEAMS. Coldstream Guards. 60th Rifles Mr. Watts Russell I. Mr. Evans I. 1-, Tollemache II. ,, Eyre II. 1. Bentinck III. Seymour III. Fuller Maitland IV., Hope (back).

2ND MATCH. K.S.C. V K.O.S.B. BORDERERS. This was a fast mateb, each side having rups up and down the ground alternately. The K.S.C. won by 4 goals to 1. Capt. Sterling played a good, unselfish game at No. 1. Both he and Mr. Merriman, made some excellent "centring" shots. In this respect this mateh was one of the best of the season. There's generally a great tendency to take the ball round. This is a fatal mistake. The K.O.S.B. As a team they are practically free from this great mistake, but the shouting for back-benders can be overdone and once especially they lost a goal in this way.
TEAMS. K.O.S.B.

div.head: VICTORIA COLLEGE FOOTBALL.
div.p: On Saturday last a football match took place on the Club ground between Victoria College and the Sporting Club A.F.C. which endell in a win for the home side, four goals nil. The School was not in their best form, being unused to grass. It is very much hoped by the boys of the College that the Sporting Club in the return match will play on the School ground, the College have always had the disadvantage of playing on the Club ground, and if the Club would be sporting enough to play the return match on their opponents ground, then the Club, would get a much better game.

div.head: THE MAMELUKES LEAP
div.p: General Tyrrell sends the following to the "Spectator" :

It is a pity to spoil a good story, and the story of the Mamelukes famous leap, which is recounted to every visitor to the citadel of Cairo, is a good one But it is a fiction founded on the fact that only a single Mameluke of the seven hundred and odd who were mustered in Cairo on that fatal morning survived the massacre ; but he survived because he was on the sick-list at the time, and was consequently unable to attend the parade in the citadel, and the Pasha, having nothing to fear from a single man, spared his life. A story never loses in the telling in the mouth of an Egyptian, and he is quite capable of inventing one to account for any incident appellation that he does not happen to understand. There were formerly two gates to the citadel of Cairo, called respectively the Gate of the Janissaries and the Gate of the Azabs, from the titles of two Turkish military corps to | whom their charge was confided in. But the existence and the very name of these corps have long been forgotten by the Egyptians, and they accounted for the name Bab el Azab by inventing a story of a saint called Sidi Azab, around whose name a whole legend of marvels and miracles bas grown up, while the little chamber in the gateway formerly occupied as the guardhouse is pointed out as the saint's heritage. By the by, Mr. Knight-Adkin in his stir ring and spirited ballad (Spectator, November 9th) has represented the massacre as occurring when the Mamluks were entering the citadel. It was when they were leaving it that it really occurred. The whole of them had entered into the lane which was their death trap before the gates at each end were closed before and behind them. The spot pointed out as the scene of the Mamelukes leap is on the terre-plein of the citadel.

div.head: CHRONIQUE FINANCIÈRE
div.p: Alexandrie, le 29 Novembre.
LA SEMAINE Le marché de lundi a été plutôt mauvais, - l'offre prédominant en général et les acheteurs

faisant défaut. On offrait surtout les valeurs dirigeantes et les titres favoris de la spéculation; mais en l'absence presque complète d'affaires la séance n'a rien eu d'intéressant. 1 L'allure du lendemain a été analogue; toutefois, en dépit de la lourdeur et du tassement général, quelques titres ont fait preuve de meilleures dispositions.

Mercredi, grâce à de meilleures nouvelles de dehors et particulièrement à la réduction du taux d'escompte, notre côté, sans avoir rien présenté de bien saillant, a cependant bénéficié d'un accroissement de transactions et d'une avance des prix, surtout en valeurs dirigeantes.

Hier l'hésitation a décidément fait place à la confiance et la retraite des vendeurs, aidant, les haussiers ont tenssi à donner au marché une vigoureuse impulsion. Aussi, bien que les af- | faires soient restées en somme limitées, on a constaté un relèvement presque général de la cote. L'attention s'est principalement concentrée sur les valeurs dirigeantes et les titres secondaires favoris de la spéculation.

Toujours à cause du raffermissement des valeurs égyptiennes à Londres, nous avons eu ce matin une consolidation de l'amélioration d'hier avec une nouvelle avance. Il y a eu sur l'ensemble de la côte un courant d'affaires assez facile et suivi, auquel nous n'étions plus habitués depuis longtemps. Pourvu qu'on continue à nous câbler de bonnes nouvelles, tout ira bien ! A signaler en particulier une bonne demande en Tramways d'Alexandrie à 141, en Préférence Beħéra à 4 1/8 et en Sidi Salem à 2 1/8.
FLUCTUATIONS DE LA CÔTE Sur une soixantaine de valeurs inscrites à la cote officielle, 17 sont en hausse et 17 en baisse, les autres demeurant stationnaires aux cours antérieurs.

Parmi les variations les plus appréciables il faut signaler la National Bank qui gagne 15/32, la Ramleh 3/8, les Privilégiées et Dividendes Tramways d'Alexandrie 7 fr. 50 et 7 fr. respec tivement, les Jouissances Eaux du Caire 15 fr.: les Privilégiées Bière du Caire perdent, au contraire, 5 francs, les Ninkovich Hôtels 3/4 de livre, la Nile Land 1/2 livre et la fondatrice Allotment 15 P.T. I

LA Delta Light et la Daira bénéficient de 3/16, l'Alexandria Water et le Comptoir de 1/8, l'obligation nouvelle Credit Foncier et la Banque d'Orient de 1 fr. 50, les Lots Turcs de 1 franc, la Banque d'Athènes de 3 francs, la Delta Land et la Land Bank de 1/16, l'ordinary Khedivial Mail de 7 pence 1/2 et l'Aboukir de 6 pence.

Les Markets, la Port Said Salt et la Salt and Soda reculent de 6 pence, la Spinning de 1/32, les Cotton Mills de 3 pence, l'Obligation ancienne Crédit Foncier de 1 fr. 50, la Cassa di Sconto de 50 centimes, les Splendid Hôtels, la Building Lands, les Cotton Ginners et les Ritz Hôtels de 1/16, l'Union Fonciere de 3/16 et l'action Allotment de 1/8.
Sur le reste de la cote il n'y a pas de change. * ments à signaler. Nos VALEURS SUR LES MARCHES EUROPEENS

Nos valeurs accusent au Stock Exchange une reprise considérable. A part l'Unifiée qui perd 1/4 à 99, la Daira "gagne 3/8 à 125 8, l'Agricole 1/4 à , la National Rank 3 4 à 20 1/2 et la Delta Láght 1/8 & 9 7/8. Cette amélioration est attribée à l'atténuation de la crise financière et plus direetement à la baisse rapide du taux privé d'escompte qui en a été la conséquence; de 6 7/8, ce taux baisse en effet à 6 1/8. C'est là un beau résultat pour la semaine.

A Paris la situation est loin d'être aussi bonne. Sans parler de l'Unifiée qui recule de 101.85 à 101.70, la Land Bank, la Banque d'Athènes et le Crédit Franeo-Egyptien avancent seulement de 1 frane, tandis que les autres valeurs demeurent' calmes ou sans affaires'.
Comme la plupart de nos titres dirigeants dépendent de Londres, on conçoit que notre place ait bénéficié de la hausse dans la mesure où la réserve des vendeurs le lui a permis.
Aux ENCHÈRES PUBLIQUES Ont été exécutés hier par voie d'enchères publiques, à Is requête de Cesana & Cie, MM. Jaaac Dib et Jean Stefas. Pour le premier

il a été vendu 25 Splendid Hôtels * 41/32, * 100 actions anciennes New Egyptian à 9.11 tt 50 nonvelles al9/-, 50 Banque d'Athènes à 110 3/4, 25 Salt & Soda à 15 , 25 Estates à 27/64, 100 Coston Mills à 17,50 Port-Sard Salt à 12/15, 50 Levant à 17/32, 100 Spinning à 17/64, 25 actions Allotment à 1 57 61 et 50 fondateurs à P.T38, 50 Ordinary Khedivial Mail à 20)6, 25 Delta Land à 19,32,25 Crédit Franco Egyptien à 4 1/16 et 5 fondateurs United à 9/16. Et pour le second, 75 General Trust (Hooker) À 7/32, 25 Estates à 13 32, 20 Building Lands à 19 16, 25 Delta Land à 1 15/64, et 2 aftions nouvelles Salt and Soda à 14/6.

Il a été vendu avant hier 100 Investment à 11/32, 100 Delte Land à 11/8 et 100 à 1 13/64, 25 Delta Light à 9 11/16 et 50 à 9 23/32, 200 Hooker & 7/32 et 200 à 15/64, 100 Salt and Soda à 14/3 et 122 à 14/1 ), 100 Karam à t.

Les 100 Comptoir Financier et Commerciall d'Egypte, figurant aux enchères de mardi, ont été vendus à 23: Quant aux 55 Commercial, Industrial and Building (Kuster), le prix d'adjudication a été de 5/32 de livre.

On avait dgà vendu lundi 1/4 Obligation Ville de Paris 1871 à 121 francs, 233 Obligations anciennes Crédit Foncier dont 25 à 2867, 25 à 2864, 25 à 287, 50 à 2874, 25 à 287, 50 à 288 33 8 288) et 126 nouvelles dont 50 à 252, 45 à 252 et 51 à 2511

On voit que ce chapitre va toujours croissant. Quelques-uns en prennent prétexte pour dire que ces ventes all gent les positions surchargées et que, aussitôt finies, le marché s'en trouvera mieux. Malheureusement, en faisant ces beaux pronostics, on oublie qu'il s'agit en l'espèce de simples formalités, comme nous avons en plusieurs fois l'occasion de le dire. Les titres vendus ne sont pas achetés en général par l'épargne et le capital et mis en portefeuille. Non, les courtiers engagés avec des clients pour le moment insolvables font vendre et ayant le plus souvent engagé eux-mêmes ces titres ils sont obligés de les racheter et pour cela ils paient des prix supérieurs à ceux du jour, afin de se les assurer. C'est ce qui explique cet appareil anomalie de valeurs acquises anx enchères à des cours supérieurs à ceux pratiqués au moment même dans la corbeille. Qu'importe d'ailleurs à ces agents de change puisqu'ils sont en perte et qu'ils s'assurent ainsi un recours contre leurs clients, dès que ceux-ci se trouveront en état de payer. Dans ces conditions, les titres vendus aux enchères passent d'une bourse en détresse dans une autre qui ne l'est guère moins. Comment peut-on voir dans cette situation un élément de hausse!

LA SITUATION FINANCIÈRE Il faut signaler à ce sujet une rentrée d'or de $350,000, a la Banque d'Angleterre. Une autre dépêche annonce que £300,000 sont rentrées le 25 et on million était attendu hier venant des Indes, ce qui améliorera sensiblement l'encaisse de la Banque. Depuis la clôture de dernier bilan hebdomadaire, les rentrées ont considérablement dépassé les sorties et la réserve de la Banque d'Angleterre est remontée de 38 3/4 à 42 7/8 %. Ceci semblerait confirmer l'opinion du "Statist" qui dit, un peu hautement peut-être, que "la Banque d'Angleterre n'a pas besoin d'or." Le marèche ile l’Escompte se détend naturellement et le hors banque est à 61/8 %

LA CRISE AMÉRICAINE. . Aujourd'hui, les nouvelles d'Amérique sont meilleures. Les dernières dépêches nous apprennent en effet qu'à la date du 23, l'importation d'or aux Etats:Unis, depuis le commencement de la crise, s'élève au chiffre de 81 millions et demi de dollars, dont la plus grande partie provient d'Angleterre. Une autre dépê. che de New-York annonçait le succès de l'emission des certificats du Trésor, destinés à venir en aide au marché monétaire. Pour mettre le produit des certificats du Trésor à la disposition du marché monétaire, M. Cortelyou rend aux banques nationales qui souscrivent 75 % de l'argent versé. Le restant est employé à augmenter les ressources du Trésor. Les sonscriptions arrivent abondamment et le sue cès de l'émission serajt déjà assuré. Le gouvernement américain espère que toute une large 'section du public qui a thesaurisé des espèces et se refusait jusqu'ici à les rendre à la circulation en les redéposant dans les Ban., ques, rendra lesdites espèces à la circulation en souscrivant aux bons da Trésor. Un journal estimait à 200 millions de dollars le montant des espèces thésaurisées depuis le commencement de la crise. L'efficacité de l'émission dépendra de la proportion pour cent qui sera souscrite par les détenteurs de numéraire qu'ils feront sortir de leurs cachettes. C'est pour favoriser ce mouvement que l'on a résolu de faire de très petites coupures afin d'attirer les achats de tris modestes capitalistes qui avaient coutume antérieurement de déposer un peu d'argent à 2 1/2 ou 3 0/0 d'intérêt dans les Trusts Com. panies. C'est ainsi qu'il a été décidé que les bons du Trésor seraient à un an afin de les rendre au placement temporaire idéal, de cours à peu près fixes, qui rentre dans les habitudes des déposants des Trust Companies anxquelles, en fait, le Trésor se substitue momentanément pour reconquérir les espèces de cette clientèle mise en défiance contre toute institution privée.

Enfin une dépêche privée de Londres nous annonce que "la panique américaine peut être considérée comme ayant atteint son maximum, mais le pays reste pratiquement en état de suspension de crédits. Les différents palliatifs adoptés sont considérés par les financiers sages comme destinés à renvoyer le jour de la debacle. Le projet le plus important est celui d'établir une Banque centrale d'émission, mais on doute quel accueil lui fera le Congrès."
LA CASSA DI SCONTO EN LIQUIDATION

Dans une assignation lancée contre les liquidateurs de la Cassa di Sconto, Emin Bey Azmy réclame la convocation immédiate des actionnaires de la société pour discuter et délibérer sur l'ordre du jour suivant :
I. Rapport des liquidateurs sur la liquidation courue a partir do 2 juillet dernier avec états de la situation.

IT: Nomination d'une commission composée de trois ou d'un plus grand nombre de membres, avec mission de s'adjoindre aux liquidateurs en fonctions aux fins d'examiner de concert, d'après les livres, régistres et documents de la Société : 1 A. Si la nonvelle émission du 11 mars 1907 a été ordonnée par le Conseil d'Administration dans des conditions normales, ou si cette nonvelle émission n'a été qu'un moyen dégnisé pour faire rentrer de nonvelles sommes d'argent dans les caisses d'une Société dont la situation, loin de correspondre aux déclarations faites par le Conseil d'Administration en son rapport Là l'Assemblée Générale du 17 mars 1907, était dès alors fortement compromise.
B. Si la liquidation prononcée le 2 juillet 1907 après la fermeture des guichets advenue

21 juin 1907 dite liquidation ayant en vue de conjurer la faillite inévitable, n'a pas été la conséquence des fautes et des erreurs de toute nature, commises par l'administrateur délégué, fautes lourdes et erreurs entrainant la responsabilité dn Conseil d'Administration qui, au lieu de surveiller et de contrôler, n'a fait preuve que d'une inconcevable et coupable négligence
III. Communication du Rapport de Russell, Kerr et Wyatt dont l'Assemblée Gérjérale du 2 Juillet 1907 n'a pas eu connaissance.
IV. Communication de Rapport du 11 Juin 1907, de M.A. Stross soumis à ses collègues du
Conseil d'Administration dit. Rapport fruit I d'un réveil tardif."

div.head: REVUE COMMERCIALE
div.p: mêmeste écheny

Coton La semaine que nous allons passer en revae offre cette singulière particularité de se trouver partagée en deux périodes, d'égale dorée. mais absolument opposées pour ce qui est de | la tenue du marché et la marche des choses.

En effet, les trois premiers jours, qui représentent ce que nous appellerons la période descendante, ont été d'une faiblesse extreme, causée non seulement par la persistance du désir intense des haussiers de liquider, mais aussi par l'allure peu favorable du disponible; tandis que de Mereredi à aujourd'hui c'est la fermeté qui a prédominé, ayant pour point de départ les rachats de deux faiseats à la baisse qui ont jugé prudent d'empocher leurs bénéfices, et encouragée ensuite par les nouvelles de l'Etranger.
Et pour résumer en chiffres ce qui s'est passé sur le marché dans ees deux phases différentes, L. nous dirons que le Janvier, qui avait cloture
la semaine passée à 19 7 32, était tombé à 18 | 25/32 pour reprendre et finir ce soir à 19 11/32.
Le Mars aussi a fluctué à 'pen près dans les mêmes proportions, la dernière cote affichée pour cette échéance étans de 20 7/82.

En somme, il n'y a rien eu de saillant et de 1/16 à 1/8 près, c'est tout simplement au niveau de Vendredi que nous sommes revenus ; mais si les deux partis en présence ont eu le suces à tour de rôle à leur actif, il n'en est pas moins vrai que cette fois les haussiers se trouvent les plus favorisés : ce n'est pas par une maneuvre quelconque qu'ils sont paryenus à faire remonter les cours, mais c'est en sachant profiter de la circonstance des rachats que nous venons de mentiomer et des nouvelles qui nous sont arrivées en dernier lieu au sujet de la crise américaine qu'ils ont réussi à faire pencher la balance de leur côté. Espérons seulement qu'ils n'iront pas une fois de plus gâter leurs propres affaires en exagérant les manipulations et qu'ils sauront attendre une consolidation de la situation.

A coup sûr, ces derniers mots vont être considérés par les adversaires de nos opinions com'ne un indice de notre penchant pour la baisse que quelques superficiels ont qualifié de "penchant de nature." C'est peut-être malgré nous que de temps à autre nous laissons poindre le bout de l'oreille, mais, en toute sincérité, peut-on nous en vouloir quand la réalité vient nons justifier plus souvent que nous ne nous y attendons ? Le Novembre n'avait-il pas atteint 20 11/16 quand nous commencions à peine de mettre la spéculation sur ses gardes et n'a till pas fini à 18 tallaris ? Dans ces conditions, c'est pour nous un honneur que d'être appelés les paladins de la baisse.

Et puis, après tout, sur quoi nous sommesnous appuyés en exposant nos idées ? Est-ce qu'on pourrait sérieusement nous contester les faits que la filáture a montré énormément de réserve dans ses achats d'égyptiens depuis plusieurs semaines et que les gros embarquements de Novembre ont été en très grande partie alimentés par les anciemmes affaires et dans quelques proportions aussi par les expéditions anticipées à la suite de la crise financièrel Ce sont-la des choses avérées et non des inventions fantaisistes ou des arguments burlesques, épithète qui pourra être mieux appliquée à cette preuve de la solidité de la situation qu'on a voulu nous fournir en relevant qu'on mouve. ment de la récolte de près de 3,000,000 Cantars présentait une augmentation dans les exportations de 46000 Cantars environ et une diminution dans le stock de 15000 Cantars ? Cela sent trop la personne dont la tâche est de prêcher et de prouver la hausse, mêine par les moyens entantins !
Et de l'énorme écart entre égyptien et américain, et de la diminution désormais sûre dans la consommation de l'égyptien par la filature américaine, qu'en faites-vous ?

Et maintenant à cetix de nos lecteurs qui ne sauraient peut-être s'expliquer cette tirade que nous venons d'intercaler dans notre revue, et pour laquelle nous leur demandons pardon, nous dirons qu'elle est tout bonnement une réponse à un nouveau confrère londonien dont le correspondant a cité quelques bouts de phrases de nos chroniques, qu'il a voulu ridiculiser dans le but évident de servir sa politique de potte étendard de la hausse. Libre à lui de ne pas nons gober; mais, pour notre part cela ne nous empêchera pas de continuer à dire toujours la vérité et à attirer l'attention de nos lecteurs sur les mauvais côtés des situations. C'est vieille école peut-être, mais notre conviction est qu'agir de la sorte c'est faire besogne loyale et indépendante.

Pour revenir au marché, nous aujouterons que sous le rapport de l'activité, il a laissé à désirer et que par moments la corbeille s'est trouvée déserte comme en plein été; depuis deux ou trois jours, cependant, il y a plus d'entr lin.
Le Novembre 1908 a denné lieu à un peu plus de transactions, mais rien de sérieux: la contre partie ne cesse d'être souvent difficile à trouver.

De la récolte on ne parle plus à la corbeille, mais ce que nous pouvons affirwer c'est qu'en général l'intérieur est pour un rendement de 6 3/4 & 7 millions de cantars. Du reste, d'ici trois ou quatre jours la Produce Association aura reçu toutes ses réponses à son questionnaire de Novembre et nous donnera son résumé qui mettra fin à toutes les controverses.

Les dépêches d'Amérique de la semaine ont été intéressantes surtout en ce qui concerne la question de la crise, il y a du mieux et beaucoup de mieux dans la situation et le fait se trouve corroboré par la chûte de l'escompte à Londres, mais tout naturellement il faudra un peu de temps avant que la plaie ne soit complètement guérie et que l'industrie cotonnière aux Etats-Unis cesse ses plaintes.

En dehors de cela, nous avons : 1. Pronostics pour le prochain Bureau de 11,900,000 balles, ce qui signifierait éventuellement pour le public | 11,500,000 balles, 2 craintes d'un petit Bureau et estimation de B. J. Burch de 10,900,000;
derniers temes
112,500,000 nation d'une
l'année dersions on dis 674,990,000, ce qui aurait stimulb loo sobats de Wall Street, dont il a été tant question ces derniers temps. | 3 une estimation d'une maison sérieuse de
12,500,000 balles et une autre de Latham Alexander and Co., généralement conservateurs, de 12,000,000 de balles.

Comme d'habitude, il ya diversité, mais la généralité semble avoir abandonné les idées de 13,500,000 balles et penche pour 12 1/2. i la consommation est bonne pour tonte l'année, il n'y aura pas plethore, mais dans tous les cas il y aura grande sufisance avec les ressources visibles et invisibles au sujet desquels nous avons dit quelques mots dans une précédente Orion.
Liverpool voit déjà meilleure demande pour les filés et les tissus et bat la grosse caisse pour la hausse.

Quant à la grève d'Oldham, elle est encore ery suspens. Ce n'est pas la question elle-urême qui a été soumise à un arbitrage, mais seulement Pinterpretation d'un article des conventions entre filateurs et fleurs sur la question des grèves qui a été soumise aux avocats de la couronne. La réponse sera donnée Mardi ou Moreredi et alors seulement on saura si une grève pourra avoir lieu ou non. Espérons encore une fois que tout s'arrangera. -

- Reuter nous a transmis la nouvelle que les planteurs comptaient proposer à la convention de Memphis, qui doit de tenit le 7 janvier, de garder de 4 à 6 millions de Balles, jusqu'à ce que le prix de 15 dents soit atteint. Mais il y aurait done au moins 15.000.000 de Balles comme réculte en Aniérique !! -

Pour ce qui est de la rédaction des ensemencements, l'expérience du passé mous enseigne que cela signifierait tout simplement que chacun comptera sur son voisin pour la rednetion, mais que pour ce qui le concerne luimême, il plantera davantage !
La demande pour le disponible s'est un peu étendue et généralisée ces jours derniers et il y a un peu plus d'affaires.
Quant aux prix, surtout pour le bon coton, ils sont formes et la cote officielle de ce jour nous les montre sans changement sur la semaive passée.
Les exportations ont dépassé toute attente avec leur total de 31,000 Balles, contre 28,000 Balles en 1906 pour la même semaine. Ce fait a contribué au raffermissement du marché hier et aujourd'hui.

Pour la semaine prochaine, il y aura de gros embarquements, mais. on croit que l'on n'arrivera pas au chiffre record de 43,000 Balles de l'année passée. On n'ose plns faire de pronosties de crainte d'être éventnellement per siflé par les haussiers, qui ont trouvé que les prévisions de 26,000 Balles pour la semaine passée constituaient nne fante impardonnable, même après que celui qui a lancé le chiffre avait dit juste pendant six à huit semaines de suite.
Liverpool n'a pas été très animé pour les Egyptiens disponibles, mais, comme prix, il y a 11/64 de hausse, sur les futurs Janvier qui finissent à 9 54/64, tandis que le spot remonte à 10 1/8.
Les américains, plus actifs, ont joui d'une hausse marquée allant de 16 à 19 points, les cours de ce soir étant de 6.18 pour le spot, 6.85 pour le Janvier-Février et 5.87, pour le MarsAvril
Gralne. de Coton

Les recettes ont été copieuses ; aussi avec la diminution des exportations cette circonstance avait-elle pesé sur le marché ; depuis deux jours, cependant, la demande est meilleure et de P.T. 67 1/2, le 'spot remonte à P.T. 69.
En contrats peu d'affaires, mais prix quand même soutenus. Derniers cours P.T. 79 1/4 pour Décembre Janvier et P.T. 74 35/40 pour Pévrier Mars. Hull est calme et n'offre que £6.13/9.
Les huiles sont toujours en baisse et les tourteaux presque invendables.
Bombay, de son coté, offre sa graine à £5.15%, soit en baisse de 2/6.

div.head: "INVESTMENTS.”
div.p:
"Investments” introduces, in an entirely original manner, new and important methods for the employment of and the means of obtaining capital. Among the
SPECIALLY CONTRIBUTED ARTICLES
are "Stock Markets and How to Profit by Them”; "Theory of Successful Speculation”; "How to start an Account” ; "The Advantages of 'Call Options'”; "Contangoing Mining and Industrial Securities” ; "How to Invest in Mines”; "American Rails, with Points for Operators in Yankees”; "The Purchase of Investment Securities by Instalments” ; "General Principles for Investors” ; "Rules for Investors in Mines”; "General Principles for Speculators”; "Stock Exchange Terms,” being a glossary for Market Operators; "Stock Exchange Parlance”; "Insurance, as a Means of Making, Raising, and Saving Money,” and "Colonial Building Land: Its Great Possibilities.”
"Investments” (148 pages) sent Post Free on mentioning "Egyptian Gazette.”
LONDON & PARIS EXCHANGE LIMITED, GENERAL BANKERS. BASILDON HOUSE, BANK, LONDON, E.C.

div.head: ARMY OF OCCUPATION.
div.p: BEEF AND MUTTON.

TENDERS were received at the Headquarters Office, Cairo, until 12 o'clock noon on Tuesday the 5th December 1907, for the supply of Beef and Mutton to the Army of Occupation at Cairo and Alexandria, for 12 months from the 1st January 1908.
Forms of Tender and all information må be obtained at the above named office of application.
* Envelopes containing Tenders should b addressed to "The General Officer Commanding
Cairo." and marked on the outside " Tenders for Meat."
The General Officer Commanding does not bind himself to accept the lowest or any Tender. E. R. O. LUDLOW,
Lient : Colonel, Commanding A. S. C. in Egypt. Cairo, November 20.

div.head: Egyptian State Railways.
div.p: NOTICE.
Trains de Laxe composed of sleeping and dining-cars, will run between Cairo and Luxo as follows :--
From Cairo every Monday, Wednesday, an Saturday, at 6.30 p.m., on and after 2n December
From Luxor every Tuesday, Thursday, and Sunday, at 6.30 pm. on and after 3rd December.
A second class carriage will be attached to these trains for passengers' servants only.
The sleeping and dining-cars on the night Expresses leaving Cairo at 8 p.m., and Luxo at 5.30 p.m., will be suppressed from the above dates.
Passengers are requested to book their birth early through the Sleeping Car Company Cairo Station
Cairo, 27th November, 1907. 31412-2

div.p: Whereas David Arditi and Silvio Francis merchants and contractors trading in Port Sudan, Khartoum and elsewhere under the name of D. This is a condition (or disease) to which doctors give many names, but which few of them really understand. It it simply weakness—a break-down, as it were, of the vital forces that sustain the system. No matter what may be its causes (for they are almost numberless), its symptoms are much the same; the more prominent being sleeplessness, sense of prostration or weariness, depression of spirits and want of energy for all the ordinary affairs of life.
